hints.content:
Does $\blueD{(9 \times 2) \times 5}=\greenD{9 \times (2 \times 5)}?$

Yes! When multiplying, we can group numbers differently by moving the parentheses and still arrive at the same answer. [[☃ explanation 1]]

This is called the **associative property of multiplication**.

options.showPrompt: Don't believe us? Check this out.

hints.content:
Does $\blueD{(9 \times 2) \times 5}=\maroonD{11 \times 5}?$

$
\begin{align}
\blueD{(9 \times 2) \times 5} &\stackrel{?}{=}  \maroonD{11 \times 5} \\\\
\blueD{18 \times 5} &\neq  \maroonD{11 \times 5}
 \end{align}$

No, $\blueD{(9 \times 2) \times 5}$ is not equivalent to $\maroonD{11 \times 5}$.

The following expressions are equivalent to $\blueD{(9 \times 2) \times 5}$:

* $\greenD{9 \times (2 \times 5)}$

* $\purpleC{9 \times 10}$

question.content:
**Which two expressions are equivalent to ${(9 \times 2) \times 5}$ ?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
